articles.headline: Weighing Jobs’s Role in a Scandal
articles.snippet: As hard as Steven P. Jobs has worked to convey the image of an above-the-fray visionary, that’s not quite the reality.
articles.abstract: As hard as Steven P. Jobs has worked to convey the image of an above-the-fray visionary, that’s not quite the reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: In June 2001, Fortune magazine put Steven P. Jobs on its cover. This, I realize, is not exactly breaking news; the magazine put Mr. Jobs on its cover with shameless regularity.

articles.headline: Citigroup Goes Global in Ad Effort
articles.snippet: Citigroup will introduce a new message in the company’s first global brand campaign since it was formed nearly a decade ago.
articles.abstract: Citigroup will introduce a new message in the company’s first global brand campaign since it was formed nearly a decade ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Citigroup has promised its customers better service and its investors better results. Now, Citigroup is pitching a new message: “Let’s Get It Done.”

articles.headline: It’s Maple Syrup Time, So Why the Whiff of French Fries?
articles.snippet: Some maple syrup producers are using used vegetable oil instead of heating oil to boil their sap in an effort to help the environment.
articles.abstract: Some maple syrup producers are using used vegetable oil instead of heating oil to boil their sap in an effort to help the environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WESTMINSTER, Vt. — Ah, early spring in Vermont. As temperatures warmed and the maples yielded up their annual crop of syrup, the hills and forests of the state were dotted with the familiar sights, sounds and smells of sugaring time.

articles.headline: Rewriting the Ad Rules for Muslim-Americans
articles.snippet: Consumer companies and advertising executives are focusing on ways to use the cultural aspects of the Muslim religion to help sell their products.
articles.abstract: Consumer companies and advertising executives are focusing on ways to use the cultural aspects of the Muslim religion to help sell their products.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, few advertisers in the United States have dared to reach out to Muslims.

articles.headline: Saudis Round Up 172, Citing Plot Against Oil Rigs
articles.snippet: Officials said a terrorist ring was planning to blow up oil installations and attack public officials and military posts.
articles.abstract: Officials said a terrorist ring was planning to blow up oil installations and attack public officials and military posts.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 27 — Saudi security officials said Friday that they had broken up a vast terrorist ring, arresting 172 men who planned to blow up oil installations, attack public officials and military posts, and storm a prison to free terrorist suspects.

articles.headline: In Apparel, All Tariffs Aren’t Created Equal
articles.snippet: The fees tacked onto clothing as it enters the U.S. may be the last legal form of sex discrimination in the country.
articles.abstract: The fees tacked onto clothing as it enters the U.S. may be the last legal form of sex discrimination in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congress, it turns out, plays fashion favorites.

articles.headline: Economy at Its Slowest in 4 Years
articles.snippet: The slowdown underscores how the persistent housing slump continues to drag on the American economy.
articles.abstract: The slowdown underscores how the persistent housing slump continues to drag on the American economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economic growth slowed to its weakest pace in four years during the first three months of 2007, underscoring how the persistent slump in the housing market continued to serve as a drag on the American economy.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: For $82 a Day, Booking a Cell in a 5-Star Jail
articles.snippet: For offenders with money, self-pay jails operate like secret velvet-roped nightclubs of the corrections world.
articles.abstract: For offenders with money, self-pay jails operate like secret velvet-roped nightclubs of the corrections world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif., April 25 — Anyone convicted of a crime knows a debt to society often must be paid in jail. But a slice of Californians willing to supplement that debt with cash (no personal checks, please) are finding that the time can be almost bearable.

articles.headline: An Agitator Speaks Up, and It Pays Off
articles.snippet: Since 2003, a Salt Lake City investment fund has successfully agitated for change at a half-dozen closed-end funds.
articles.abstract: Since 2003, a Salt Lake City investment fund has successfully agitated for change at a half-dozen closed-end funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: RATIONAL, constructive shareholder activism doesn’t always make directors more accountable — and it rarely gives investors immediate payoffs. But miracles can happen, as shown last week when a shareholder and a board squared off in a proxy fight at two closed-end real estate stock funds.

articles.headline: Vudu Casts Its Spell on Hollywood
articles.snippet: A Silicon Valley startup hopes to turn America’s televisions into limitless multiplexes, changing the landscape of the home entertainment business.
articles.abstract: A Silicon Valley startup hopes to turn America’s televisions into limitless multiplexes, changing the landscape of the home entertainment business.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR the last two years, the employees of Vudu Inc. have quietly toiled in a nondescript office in Santa Clara, Calif., in the heart of Silicon Valley. The only hint of the company’s plans are black-and-white Rat Pack photos that adorn its walls and oversized models of Gollum and R2D2 that watch over its cubicles.

articles.headline: Inspectors Find Rebuilt Projects Crumbling in Iraq
articles.snippet: Inspectors found that in a sampling of eight projects declared successes by the U.S., seven were no longer operating as designed.
articles.abstract: Inspectors found that in a sampling of eight projects declared successes by the U.S., seven were no longer operating as designed.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a troubling sign for the American-financed rebuilding program in Iraq, inspectors for a federal oversight agency have found that in a sampling of eight projects that the United States had declared successes, seven were no longer operating as designed because of plumbing and electrical failures, lack of proper maintenance, apparent looting and expensive equipment that lay idle.

articles.headline: Teed Up: Golf, K Street and Nigeria
articles.snippet: The story of how a luxury golf resort came to a remote corner of Africa’s most populous country is part of a larger tale in which American deal makers played leading roles.
articles.abstract: The story of how a luxury golf resort came to a remote corner of Africa’s most populous country is part of a larger tale in which American deal makers played leading roles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uyo, Nigeria

articles.headline: At Whole Foods, a Welcome Sign for Immigrants Seeking Jobs
articles.snippet: Immigrants and refugees can receive a leg up through a pre-interview training program supported by Whole Foods Market and a social services group.
articles.abstract: Immigrants and refugees can receive a leg up through a pre-interview training program supported by Whole Foods Market and a social services group.
articles.lead_paragraph: WANGLA LAMA, 37, of Queens, has long supported himself by working in restaurant kitchens. In his native Nepal, when he was not employed as a mountain guide, he made his living as a cook. For most of his nine years in the United States, he worked in a Japanese restaurant in Manhattan, he said, rising from busboy to cook, until it closed in February.

articles.headline: Uneasy Alliance Is Taming One Insurgent Bastion
articles.snippet: Sunni leaders have united with U.S. and Iraqi forces in Anbar Province, heartland of the Sunni resistance.
articles.abstract: Sunni leaders have united with U.S. and Iraqi forces in Anbar Province, heartland of the Sunni resistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMADI, Iraq — Anbar Province, long the lawless heartland of the tenacious Sunni Arab resistance, is undergoing a surprising transformation. Violence is ebbing in many areas, shops and schools are reopening, police forces are growing and the insurgency appears to be in retreat.

articles.headline: Social Networking Leaves Confines of the Computer
articles.snippet: Powerful new mobile devices are allowing people to send round-the-clock updates about every detail of their lives.
articles.abstract: Powerful new mobile devices are allowing people to send round-the-clock updates about every detail of their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 — While Walter Zai was in South Africa watching the wild animals recently, people around the world were watching him.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Iran to Attend Regional Talks on Iraq Violence
articles.snippet: The stage is set for the first cabinet-level meeting between Iran and the U.S. since the end of 2004.
articles.abstract: The stage is set for the first cabinet-level meeting between Iran and the U.S. since the end of 2004.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 29 — The government of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran announced Sunday that it would attend a regional conference on Iraq later this week, setting the stage for the first cabinet-level meeting between Iran and the United States since the end of 2004.

articles.headline: Minky Viagra? Pfizer Doesn’t Want You to Understand It, Just Buy It
articles.snippet: Pfizer has always straddled a line marketing Viagra, insisting that the drug treats a serious medical condition while promoting it with wink-and-a-nod ads.
articles.abstract: Pfizer has always straddled a line marketing Viagra, insisting that the drug treats a serious medical condition while promoting it with wink-and-a-nod ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much sexual innuendo can an advertiser pack into 15 seconds?

articles.headline: A Flood Begets a Paper Ark
articles.snippet: The Times-Picayune of New Orleans has become a beacon of tough questions, vigorous reporting and high-quality, relentlessly local coverage.
articles.abstract: The Times-Picayune of New Orleans has become a beacon of tough questions, vigorous reporting and high-quality, relentlessly local coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a visiting newspaper guy, the coffee shop in New Orleans last Thursday morning looked like some kind of golden age fantasy. People at every table, regardless of race, class or age, seemed to have a newspaper open, chatting over the articles and trading sections back and forth. Even the people who were hunched over computers seemed mostly using the connection to link to the newspaper.

articles.headline: Consortium Buys Control of Italy’s Phone Giant
articles.snippet: A deal may ensure an Italian face remains on Telecom Italia.
articles.abstract: A deal may ensure an Italian face remains on Telecom Italia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID, April 29 — Telefónica of Spain and a group of Italian investors agreed on Saturday to pay 4.1 billion euros ($5.6 billion) for a controlling 18 percent stake in Telecom Italia, allowing the Spanish telecommunications giant to expand into the Italian market and extend its presence in Latin America.
articles.byline: By Victoria Burnett and Peter Kiefer

articles.headline: A Candidate, His Minister and the Search for Faith
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s campaign has put a strain on the close relationship he forged over 20 years with his pastor.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s campaign has put a strain on the close relationship he forged over 20 years with his pastor.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Members of Trinity United Church of Christ squeezed into a downtown hotel ballroom in early March to celebrate the long service of their pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. One congregant stood out amid the flowers and finery: Senator Barack Obama, there to honor the man who led him from skeptic to self-described Christian.

articles.headline: Filler in Animal Feed Is Open Secret in China
articles.snippet: Animal feed has been regularly supplemented with a cheap additive that is at the center of a pet food recall.
articles.abstract: Animal feed has been regularly supplemented with a cheap additive that is at the center of a pet food recall.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHANGQIU, China, April 28  As American food safety regulators head to China to investigate how a chemical made from coal found its way into pet food that killed dogs and cats in the United States, workers in this heavily polluted northern city openly admit that the substance is routinely added to animal feed as a fake protein.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Alexei Barrionuevo

articles.headline: As Health Plan Falters, Maine Explores Changes
articles.snippet: So far, Maine has not come close to its goal of covering some 130,000 residents without insurance by ’09.
articles.abstract: So far, Maine has not come close to its goal of covering some 130,000 residents without insurance by ’09.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me., April 23 — When Maine became the first state in years to enact a law intended to provide universal health care, one of its goals was to cover the estimated 130,000 residents who had no insurance by 2009, starting with 31,000 of them by the end of 2005, the program’s first year.

articles.headline: After Virginia Tech, Testing Limits of Movie Violence
articles.snippet: “Hostel: Part II,” a film about the torture killing of college students, is emerging as a test of continued audience enthusiasm for such onscreen brutality.
articles.abstract: “Hostel: Part II,” a film about the torture killing of college students, is emerging as a test of continued audience enthusiasm for such onscreen brutality.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, April 29 — If the horror at Virginia Tech has changed the chemistry of America’s popular culture, those who count box-office receipts at Lionsgate would be among the first to know.
